item.title:
"We stand with you, this is not your fault"â€”Malala Yousafzai sends a message to young people in Ukraine.
To mark #IWD2022, @Malala and @zannymb discuss how to improve the lives of women and girls everywhere.
Subscribers can sign up to watch here: https://t.co/Cg6G1x8syd https://t.co/LVYMJyICAn
Joe Biden is as unpopular as Donald Trump had become at this point in his presidency. He was in especially poor form, stumbling through both scripted lines and ad libs https://t.co/kK56kGdwa1
As Ukrainians flee the country, guns and missiles are entering. But delivering arms is hazardous. We explain how it is being done https://t.co/RlhB2RQ0go
After a little more than one year in office, the president is in a slump. His answers to Americaâ€™s domestic ailments were unsatisfying https://t.co/RNTmMFzSvx
Volodymyr Zelensky has requested that the West â€œimpose a no-fly zone over significant parts of Ukraineâ€. We explain what the measure is, and why it comes at a cost https://t.co/qmbAc6N4fU

â™¦ï¸ Russiaâ€™s defence ministry claims that its forces have taken control of the port city of Kherson. Local authorities deny this.
â™¦ï¸ Ukrainian officials say airborne Russian troops have landed in Kharkiv.
â™¦ï¸ Putin must â€œpay a priceâ€, Biden warns.
Catch up on Ukraine â¬‡ï¸
China is treading a very fine line on Ukraine, @gadyepsteinâ€”one of our China specialistsâ€”tells â€œThe Intelligenceâ€ https://t.co/obJ53RC602
After images of Russiaâ€™s attack began to circulate on social media, the share of Britons in favour of sending weapons to Ukraine rose from 46% to 60% https://t.co/nxdiq8ebD7
Half a century after China blasted the Soviet invasion of Czechoslovakia, the world order is turned upside-down https://t.co/sANt1zmHp9
Three-quarters of Ukrainians aged over 13 are active on social media. They are the ones filming the videos of war that catch the worldâ€™s attention https://t.co/fzgbmNCtG1

Vladimir Putinâ€™s nuclear threat shows how much is going wrong for him in Ukraine. Why won't Russia leave its neighbour alone?
Read our latest analysis on the invasion: https://t.co/Ku48sueqh2 https://t.co/yDCDgXLqFT

Even with sophisticated methods at its disposal, Russia has â€œvery differentâ€ targeting principles from those of NATO countries, says an analyst at the Royal United Services Institute https://t.co/pVf20u31nX
Russia has not recognised the International Criminal Court since 2016, when the court classified its annexation of Crimea as an occupation https://t.co/nEFwDLRg6J
Volodymyr Zelensky is an avid user of social mediaâ€”his Instagram following is the fifth-biggest of any world leader. Now other Ukrainian officials have followed his lead https://t.co/VvOTCxbsbO
â€œItâ€™s not the fault of the Russian citizens,â€ said Vova, looking up from his phone, â€œitâ€™s the fault of Putin.â€ @wendell23's dispatch from Ukraine in @1843mag https://t.co/Cvu5NkinfL
It is one thing to think Russia is in breach of international laws, quite another to bring any Russian, let alone its head of state, to the world court https://t.co/N3LeDySkaz
China and Russia agree that big countries should run the world https://t.co/KWC1Wgkmju
There is prima facie evidence that Russia has committed at least three of the four main crimes prosecuted by the International Criminal Court https://t.co/UMKCqzjQpE
Russiaâ€™s recent strikes in Kharkiv and other cities show little sign of any effort to identify enemy forces https://t.co/JwdfWmXae7
There is no serious doubt that Russia has broken international law in Ukraine https://t.co/hh92XqWnz7
On the morning of March 1st President Volodymyr Zelensky announced he was putting an experienced soldier in charge of governing the capital https://t.co/pJ7ZZqOiQG
Kyiv has the deepest metro station in the world. Now itâ€™s being used as a bomb shelter. From @1843mag https://t.co/yDEkdyDuuu
The EUâ€™s borders, which have been closed ever more tightly to most refugees since a big influx from Syria and Afghanistan in 2015-16, are opening up for Ukrainians https://t.co/zxzQJD1Yzj
The goal may be to spread terror https://t.co/3hYaS5jtzH
Ukraineâ€™s capital is not yet surrounded, but may soon be https://t.co/hM3UxXsVTw
Volodymyr Zelensky said that the missiles that recently fell on Kharkiv were deliberately targeted at civilians and described the attack as a war crime https://t.co/JfESC9js1d
The Russian authorities have responded by tightening their grip on the internet https://t.co/31MNZAPCRX
After images of Russiaâ€™s attack began to circulate on social media, the share of Britons in favour of sending weapons to Ukraine rose from 46% to 60% https://t.co/sujpg4dhxI
But many are heading the other way. Scores of Ukrainians, most of them without military experience, are heading home to enlist https://t.co/DoNJwKTgpu
â€œWe all help one another and try to comfort each other.â€ Since Russiaâ€™s invasion of Ukraine began â€œThe Intelligenceâ€ has been speaking daily to a resident of Kharkiv https://t.co/DzE1HiWr7h
The Russian authorities have responded by tightening their grip on the internet https://t.co/J11NkN3YVO

Russian state-owned media organisations have been banned or restricted in many countries. But inside Russia, how is its propaganda machine talking about the war in Ukraine? We explain â¬‡ï¸ https://t.co/38JErSF03T
But the truth is breaking through https://t.co/CTVurOjmz6
For young people in Russia, opposition has long been met with intimidation. 1843 magazine met some of them last year https://t.co/Yckc6VIfHN
Almost all Ukrainians say they wish to return to their homeland and rebuild it when the war ends. But no one knows when or how that will happen https://t.co/aYsitMZvZt
Ukrainian refugees are more to the Polish governmentâ€™s liking than Syrians and Afghans. It began building a fence along its border to keep them out in 2015 https://t.co/Xrbun97E7x

Within and outside Russia, people are joining the online protest against war in Ukraine, using the hashtag #Ð½ÐµÑ‚Ð²Ð¾Ð¹Ð½Ðµ, which means â€œno warâ€.
Read how Russian authorities have responded by tightening their grip on the internet â¬‡ï¸

Where in Russia do people oppose the war? I tracked the use of protest hashtag #Ð½ÐµÑ‚Ð²Ð¾Ð¹Ð½ÐµI ("no war"), and found opposition in all of Russiaâ€™s 50 largest cities, in all 11 time zones and in 83 out of 85 federal subjects. https://t.co/OW0p1Ipo5b
Vladimir Putinâ€™s gamble on a quick war has failedâ€”now he appears set on a grim one https://t.co/LnLAyzzWmi

â™¦ï¸ A Russian missile struck the government district in Kharkiv.
â™¦ï¸ Alexander Lukashenko insisted that Belarusian forces would not take part in the fighting.
â™¦ï¸ YouTube banned RT and Sputnik, two Russian state-owned media organisations, across Europe.
Stay up to dateðŸ‘‡
On both sides of the Atlantic foreign-policy analysts expressed astonishment at the swiftness and severity of the international response https://t.co/yfmDQ1WQag
Rockets and cluster munitions have begun targeting residential areas in Kharkiv, causing widespread damage to entire blocks of flats. Images show corpses littering the street https://t.co/wE3b5xWWdN
Uruguayâ€™s capital may lack glamour, but it is short of corruption, too https://t.co/gxyNEURHwH
If Vladimir Putinâ€™s aim was to cause panic and demoralise his enemy as cease-fire talks began in Belarus, he failed https://t.co/tig5VsHWYA
Vladimir Putin claims Russia is not conducting a war, but a nearly bloodless military operation to free its Ukrainian brothers. But the truth is breaking through https://t.co/xJi3b25Zua
The Russian invasion of Ukraine is not going to plan. The president has made three key mistakes https://t.co/zEFomIpP3u

Ukrainian men aged 18-60 are subject to conscription and banned from leaving the country. Such rules create heartbreaking scenes at the border, where mainly women and children are crossing https://t.co/ZL59Q1HMBf
The bulk of Russian forces are within 25km of Kyiv. They may try to encircle it within days. This map shows how troops have advanced https://t.co/al0OtVwoob
The war may be entering an â€œuglier stageâ€, in which Russia may not work as hard at avoiding civilian casualties https://t.co/z8mU5ORpn9
